questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:
A catchment (drainage basin) is a geographical area that drains to a given point along a river. Geologists studied catchments to understand relationships between climate, the quantities of water flowing through the catchments, and the erosion of the landscape.

Study 1
Eight catchments of similar area in different locations were chosen for study: 3 with limestone bedrock, 2 with quartzite bedrock, and 3 with granite bedrock. The dissolved load (weathered material carried in solution by water) and the solid load (solid particles carried by water) were measured for each catchment, in tons per square kilometer per year (tons/km2/yr). The rate at which the landscape was being eroded in each catchment, in centimeters per 1,000 years (cm/1,000 yr), was also measured. The results are in Table 1.


Study 2
Measurements were taken of the average annual air temperature, in degrees Celsius (°C), and the total annual precipitation, in cm, within the 8 catchments. The results are in Table 2.


Study 3
Geologists measured the discharge from each catchment. Discharge is the amount of water, in cubic meters per second (m3/sec), leaving a catchment. Annual precipitation from Study 2 was plotted against average discharge for the 8 catchments. The results are in Figure 1.
questions.question: 1. According to the information in Study 3, which of the following statements best describes the relationship between total annual precipitation and average discharge?

choices.A: As total annual precipitation increases, average discharge increases.
choices.B: As total annual precipitation increases, average discharge stays the same.
choices.C: As total annual precipitation increases, average discharge decreases.
choices.D: As total annual precipitation increases, average discharge increases, then decreases.

Study 3

questions.question: 2. Which of the following figures best represents the relationship between erosion rate in limestone bedrock catchments and total annual precipitation?

questions.question: 3. If, during a given year, Catchment C had received 300 cm of precipitation, according to Study 3, the average discharge for Catchment C would most likely have been:

choices.C: between 8 and 12 m3/sec.
choices.D: over 12 m3/sec.

questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:

Study 2
Measurements were taken of the average annual air temperature, in degrees Celsius (°C), and the total annual precipitation, in cm, within the 8 catchments. The results are in Table 2.


Study 3
Geologists measured the discharge from each catchment. Discharge is the amount of water, in cubic meters per second (m3/sec), leaving a catchment. Annual precipitation from Study 2 was plotted against average discharge for the 8 catchments. The results are in Figure 1.
questions.question: 4.  According to Study 2, which of the following statements best describes the relationship, if any, between average annual air temperature and total annual precipitation?

choices.A: As average annual air temperature increases, total annual precipitation increases.
choices.B: As average annual air temperature increases, total annual precipitation stays the same.
choices.C: As average annual air temperature increases, total annual precipitation decreases.
choices.D: There is no clear relationship between average annual air temperature and total annual precipitation.

questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:
A catchment (drainage basin) is a geographical area that drains to a given point along a river. Geologists studied catchments to understand relationships between climate, the quantities of water flowing through the catchments, and the erosion of the landscape.

Study 1
Eight catchments of similar area in different locations were chosen for study: 3 with limestone bedrock, 2 with quartzite bedrock, and 3 with granite bedrock. The dissolved load (weathered material carried in solution by water) and the solid load (solid particles carried by water) were measured for each catchment, in tons per square kilometer per year (tons/km2/yr). The rate at which the landscape was being eroded in each catchment, in centimeters per 1,000 years (cm/1,000 yr), was also measured. The results are in Table 1.


Study 2
Measurements were taken of the average annual air temperature, in degrees Celsius (°C), and the total annual precipitation, in cm, within the 8 catchments. The results are in Table 2.


Study 3
Geologists measured the discharge from each catchment. Discharge is the amount of water, in cubic meters per second (m3/sec), leaving a catchment. Annual precipitation from Study 2 was plotted against average discharge for the 8 catchments. The results are in Figure 1.
questions.question: 5. Dissolved load in a catchment is produced by chemical weathering, while solid load is produced by mechanical weathering. According to this information and the results of Study 1, which of the following statements about weathering is most likely true?

choices.A: Limestone is more susceptible to mechanical than to chemical weathering.
choices.B: Limestone is more susceptible to chemical than to mechanical weathering.
choices.C: Quartzite is more susceptible to chemical than to mechanical weathering.
choices.D: Quartzite is equally susceptible to chemical and to mechanical weathering.

questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:
A catchment (drainage basin) is a geographical area that drains to a given point along a river. Geologists studied catchments to understand relationships between climate, the quantities of water flowing through the catchments, and the erosion of the landscape.

Eight catchments of similar area in different locations were chosen for study: 3 with limestone bedrock, 2 with quartzite bedrock, and 3 with granite bedrock. Study 2

Geologists measured the discharge from each catchment. Discharge is the amount of water, in cubic meters per second (m3/sec), leaving a catchment. Annual precipitation from Study 2 was plotted against average discharge for the 8 catchments. The results are in Figure 1.
questions.question: 6. According to the information in Studies 1 and 2, if 3 limestone-based catchments of similar area to those in Study 1 were studied in an area having a total annual precipitation less than 25 cm, which of the following predictions could be made about loads or erosion rates in those catchments?

choices.A: The erosion rates would be less than 1 cm/1,000 yr.
choices.B: The erosion rates would be greater than 2 cm/1,000 yr.
choices.C: The dissolved load would be greater than 50 tons/km2/yr.
choices.D: The solid load would be between 4 and 6 tons/km2/yr.

questions.title: Passage ll
questions.article:
Life on Earth contains organic compounds (compounds containing carbon and other elements). The earliest compounds on Earth were inorganic. Scientists discuss 2 hypotheses about Earth's first organic compounds.

Hydrothermal Vent Hypothesis
Organic molecules were first formed several billion years ago in numerous hydrothermal vents on the deep seafloor. These vents were openings in the seafloor that spew magma-heated water. Scientists estimated that water temperatures ranged from 700° C in the deepest part of a vent to 10° C at the top of a vent (the seafloor opening). Laboratory experiments have shown that temperature gradients (increases or decreases in temperature in relationship to distance) promote chemical reactions. This natural temperature gradient provided the optimum conditions for the following events. Inorganic molecules were heated in the deep part of the vents, creating organic molecules. Seawater circulating through the vents cooled and preserved these organic molecules, which were then deposited onto clay lining the top of the vents. The clay particles provided irregular surfaces where the organic molecules became embedded. The organic molecules eventually combined to first form polymers (long chains of organic molecules) and, later, living, self-replicating cells.

Outer Space Hypothesis
Organic molecules were brought to Earth by bodies from space. Craters on other planets show that the solar system has been bombarded by asteroids, comets, and meteoroids since its formation. A meteorite (a meteoroid that strikes Earth) was found to contain amino acids (components of protein) and parts of DNA (carbon-based molecules found in living cells). Some meteorites are up to 5% organic material. Studies have found that comets contain organic material. Microscopic interplanetary dust particles fall to Earth from space in large numbers and are up to 10% organic material. These 3 types of bodies brought organic molecules to Earth. In the deep oceans, several billion years ago, conditions were right for those organic molecules to combine to form polymers and, eventually, living, self-replicating cells.
questions.question: 7. The Hydrothermal Vent Hypothesis would be strengthened by finding that the chemical reactions that produce organic compounds occur most readily at temperatures:

choices.C: between 700° C and 1,000°C.
choices.D: above 1,000°C.

questions.question: 8. Based on the information in both hypotheses, which of the following was one of the first characteristics exhibited by living things on Earth?

choices.C: The ability to digest clay crystals
choices.D: The ability to survive on land

questions.question: 9. The scientists supporting both hypotheses would agree that life on Earth first began:

choices.C: on another planet.
choices.D: on land.

questions.question: 10. The Outer Space Hypothesis makes the assumption that, billions of years ago, Earth was:.

choices.A: the only planet in the solar system with volcanoes.
choices.C: bombarded by bodies from outer space.
choices.D: much colder than it is today.

questions.question: 11. If it was discovered that organic molecules had existed on Earth before oceans existed on Earth, how would this discovery affect the hypotheses, if at all?

choices.A: It is consistent with the Outer Space Hypothesis only.
choices.B: It is consistent with the Hydrothermal Vent Hypothesis only.
choices.C: It is consistent with both hypotheses.
choices.D: It would have no effect on either hypothesis.

questions.question: 12. Based on the information in both hypotheses, in order for life to have evolved on Earth, organic compounds had to first form:

choices.C: polymers.
choices.D: clay particles.

questions.question: 13. It is estimated that 100,000 times as much collective mass of interplanetary dust particles landed on Earth as the collective mass of meteorites, comets, and asteroids that landed on Earth. Based on this information, which of the following generalizations would most likely be made by the supporters of the Outer Space Hypothesis?

choices.A: Only interplanetary dust particles brought organic molecules to Earth.
choices.B: Only meteoroids brought organic molecules to Earth.
choices.C: Most organic molecules were brought to Earth by interplanetary dust particles.
choices.D: Most organic molecules were brought to Earth by asteroids.

questions.title: Passage lll
questions.article: The 3 sets of graphs below represent the motion of 3 different motorbikes on a straight track. The top graph in each set shows the distance of the motorbike from the starting line versus elapsed time. The middle graph in each set shows the velocity of the motorbike versus elapsed time. The bottom graph in each set shows the acceleration of the motorbike (the rate at which the motorbike's velocity changes) versus elapsed time.
questions.question: 14. According to the distance versus time graphs, which motorbike(s) is(are) NOT at the starting line at time = 0?

choices.C: Motorbikes 1 and 2 only
choices.D: Motorbikes 2 and 3 only

questions.title: Passage lll
questions.article: The 3 sets of graphs below represent the motion of 3 different motorbikes on a straight track. The top graph in each set shows the distance of the motorbike from the starting line versus elapsed time. The middle graph in each set shows the velocity of the motorbike versus elapsed time. The bottom graph in each set shows the acceleration of the motorbike (the rate at which the motorbike's velocity changes) versus elapsed time.
questions.question: 15. The graphs in Set 2 could also represent which of the following descriptions of the motion of a car traveling on a street?

choices.A: A car travels at a constant velocity for a period of time, then decreases in velocity until it reaches a specific velocity, and continues traveling at that velocity.
choices.B: A car is stopped along a curb. It then increases in velocity until it reaches a specific velocity, and continues to travel at that velocity.
choices.C: A car travels at a constant velocity for a period of time, then increases in velocity until it reaches a specific velocity, and continues traveling at that velocity.
choices.D: A car is stopped at an intersection. It then increases in velocity until it reaches a specific velocity, then immediately decreases in velocity to come to a second stop.

questions.title: Passage lll
questions.article: The 3 sets of graphs below represent the motion of 3 different motorbikes on a straight track. The top graph in each set shows the distance of the motorbike from the starting line versus elapsed time. The middle graph in each set shows the velocity of the motorbike versus elapsed time. The bottom graph in each set shows the acceleration of the motorbike (the rate at which the motorbike's velocity changes) versus elapsed time.
questions.question: 16. In the acceleration versus time graphs for the motorbikes, positive acceleration values are graphed above the horizontal (time) axis and negative acceleration values are graphed below the horizontal axis. The velocity of the motorbike with negative acceleration:

choices.C: decreases.
choices.D: increases.

questions.title: Passage lll
questions.article: The 3 sets of graphs below represent the motion of 3 different motorbikes on a straight track. The top graph in each set shows the distance of the motorbike from the starting line versus elapsed time. The middle graph in each set shows the velocity of the motorbike versus elapsed time. The bottom graph in each set shows the acceleration of the motorbike (the rate at which the motorbike's velocity changes) versus elapsed time.
questions.question: 17. When a motorbike travels forward on the track, it has positive velocity; if it were to travel in reverse, it would have negative velocity. Which of the following descriptions of motion would result in a velocity versus time graph with both positive and negative velocity values?

choices.A: A baseball is tossed back and forth between two people.
choices.B: A boulder falls off a cliff to the ground.
choices.C: A sandbag is passed from person to person in a line.
choices.D: A balloon is released and floats to the ceiling.

questions.title: Passage lll
questions.article: The 3 sets of graphs below represent the motion of 3 different motorbikes on a straight track. The top graph in each set shows the distance of the motorbike from the starting line versus elapsed time. The middle graph in each set shows the velocity of the motorbike versus elapsed time. The bottom graph in each set shows the acceleration of the motorbike (the rate at which the motorbike's velocity changes) versus elapsed time.
questions.question: 18. The statement “If an object's acceleration is zero during a time period, then the object's velocity is zero during that period" is contradicted by which segment of the graphs in Set 3?

choices.A: Point A to Point B only
choices.B: Point A to Point C only
choices.C: Point B to Point C only
choices.D: Point C to Point D only

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article: Table 1 lists data about metal elements arranged in order of increasing atomic number (the number of protons contained in one atom). The melting point is the temperature at which a solid metal liquefies. An electrically neutral atom has an equal number of protons (positively charged particles) and electrons (negatively charged particles). A positive ion is formed when an atom loses one or more electrons. The first ionization energy is the energy that removes one electron from the neutral atom to form a＋1 ion. The atomic radius and ionic radius indicate the size of the neutral atom and of the +2 ion, respectively.
questions.question: 19. When iron ore is reacted with coke and limestone at a high temperature, iron (Fe) is produced in its molten (liquid) state. At which of the following temperatures can the Fe be drained or poured out of the reactor?

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article: Table 1 lists data about metal elements arranged in order of increasing atomic number (the number of protons contained in one atom). The melting point is the temperature at which a solid metal liquefies. An electrically neutral atom has an equal number of protons (positively charged particles) and electrons (negatively charged particles). A positive ion is formed when an atom loses one or more electrons. The first ionization energy is the energy that removes one electron from the neutral atom to form a＋1 ion. The atomic radius and ionic radius indicate the size of the neutral atom and of the +2 ion, respectively.
questions.question: 20. Which of the following statements best describes the relationship, if any, between the atomic number and the melting point for the metals in Table 1 ? As the atomic number increases, the melting point:

choices.C: decreases and then increases.
choices.D: shows no relationship to atomic number.

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article: Table 1 lists data about metal elements arranged in order of increasing atomic number (the number of protons contained in one atom). An electrically neutral atom has an equal number of protons (positively charged particles) and electrons (negatively charged particles). The atomic radius and ionic radius indicate the size of the neutral atom and of the +2 ion, respectively.
questions.question: 21. Which element would require the LEAST amount of energy to form a+1 ion?

choices.C: V
choices.D: Cr

An electrically neutral atom has an equal number of protons (positively charged particles) and electrons (negatively charged particles). questions.question: 22. For the metals listed in Table 1, which of the following statements best describes the relationship between atomic radius and ionic radius? For any element the:

choices.A: atom is larger than its positive ion.
choices.B: atom is smaller than its positive ion.
choices.C: size of the atom and its positive ion increases with the melting point.
choices.D: size of the atom and its positive ion increases with the ionization energy.

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article: Table 1 lists data about metal elements arranged in order of increasing atomic number (the number of protons contained in one atom). The melting point is the temperature at which a solid metal liquefies. An electrically neutral atom has an equal number of protons (positively charged particles) and electrons (negatively charged particles). A positive ion is formed when an atom loses one or more electrons. The first ionization energy is the energy that removes one electron from the neutral atom to form a＋1 ion. The atomic radius and ionic radius indicate the size of the neutral atom and of the +2 ion, respectively.
questions.question: 23. The second ionization energy is the energy needed to remove one electron from the +1 ion. For Zn, this energy is 1, 733 kJ/mole. How much energy is required to change the neutral Zn atom into its +2 ion?

choices.C: 1,733 kJ/mole - 906 kJ/mole
choices.D: 1,733 kJ/mole + 906 kJ/mole

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article:
Seeds from 100 plants of an annual wildflower species were collected and their mass (weight) was determined (Figure 1).



The seeds were divided into 3 groups. One group was planted in pots in a greenhouse. The second group was planted in meadow sites that had been cleared of vegetation. The third group was planted in meadow sites that had not been cleared of vegetation. The resultant plants were dried after flowering. Plants and seeds were weighed separately. Figure 2 shows the mass of the plants.
questions.question: 24. According to Figure 1, the largest percentage of seeds collected had masses between:

choices.C: 1.1 mg and 1.5 mg.
choices.D: 1.6 mg and 2.0 mg.

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article:

The third group was planted in meadow sites that had not been cleared of vegetation. The resultant plants were dried after flowering. Plants and seeds were weighed separately. Figure 2 shows the mass of the plants.
questions.question: 25. It was hypothesized that seeds under 0.5 mg did not contain enough stored nutrients to produce plants under any conditions. The data for which of the following sțudy site(s) in Figure 2 disprove this hypothesis?

choices.C: The greenhouse pots and the cleared meadow sites only
choices.D: The cleared meadow sites and the uncleared meadow sites only

questions.question: 26. According to Figure 3, the average mass of the seeds produced by plants grown in the greenhouse from 2 mg parent seeds was approximately:

questions.article:

Figure 2 shows the mass of the plants.
questions.question: 27. If one were to compare the masses of plants, for a given parent seed mass, as shown in Figure 2, one would conclude that the mass of the plants was greatest for plants grown in the:

choices.A: cleared meadow sites and was smallest for plants grown in the uncleared meadow sites.
choices.B: cleared meadow sites and was smallest for plants grown in the greenhouse.
choices.C: greenhouse pots and was smallest for plants grown in the uncleared meadow sites.
choices.D: greenhouse pots and was smallest for plants grown in the cleared meadow sites.

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article:
Seeds from 100 plants of an annual wildflower species were collected and their mass (weight) was determined (Figure 1).



The seeds were divided into 3 groups. One group was planted in pots in a greenhouse. The second group was planted in meadow sites that had been cleared of vegetation. The third group was planted in meadow sites that had not been cleared of vegetation. The resultant plants were dried after flowering. Plants and seeds were weighed separately. Figure 2 shows the mass of the plants.
questions.question: 28. Assume that a 0.9 mg seed of this wildflower species was planted in an uncleared site. What would one most likely observe, according to Figures 2 and 3?

choices.A: The plant would grow but would not produce seeds.
choices.B: The plant would grow and produce a large number of small seeds only.
choices.C: The plant would grow and produce a small number of very large seeds only.
choices.D: The plant would grow and produce seeds in a variety of masses.

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article:
Plants produce food by photosynthesis, summarized as follows:

Light can be described by a wavelength, measured here in nanometers (nm). Each color of the rainbow has its own range of wavelengths. Plants contain cells with colored pigments that absorb various wavelengths of light. Researchers conducted 3 studies to examine the role of light's wavelengths and plant pigments on photosynthesis.

Study 1
A prism was used to shine a rainbow of colors on living algae. Bacteria that require oxygen for survival were added to the algae. Most of the bacteria were found around the region of algae exposed to red and orange light. A smaller number were found in the blue light region and a few were also found in other regions.

Study 2
The effect of different colors of light on photosynthesis was tested by exposing, groups of bean plants to light of specific wavelengths. Sugar production of each group of plants was measured and used as an estimate of the rate of photosynthesis at each wavelength. Figure 1 shows the action spectrum of photosynthesis, which is the effect of light of different wavelengths on photosynthesis.

Study 3
Solutions of 3 different photosynthetic pigments, isolated from plant cells, were each exposed to light of a specific wavelength. Figure 2 shows the absorption spectrum, which is the percentage light absorbance of various wavelengths for each pigment.


Figures adapted from Claude A. Villee, Eldra P. Solomon, and P. William Davis, Biology. ©1985 by CBS College Publishing.
questions.question: 29. According to the results of Study 2, if plants are exposed to only a narrow range of wavelengths of light, which of the following ranges would produce the greatest rate of photosynthesis?

Figures adapted from Claude A. Villee, Eldra P. Solomon, and P. William Davis, Biology. ©1985 by CBS College Publishing.
questions.question: 30. In Study 1, the bacteria probably clustered around the photosynthesizing algae in areas where the algae were releasing the most:

choices.C: carbon dioxide.
choices.D: energy.

questions.question: 31. The results from which of the studies, if any, support the conclusion that as the intensity of light increases, photosynthetic activity increases?

choices.C: Studies 1 and 2 only
choices.D: None of the studies support this conclusion.

questions.question: 32. The color of a substance results from the wavelengths of light that it does NOT absorb. According to the results of Study 3, one would predict that the color of carotenoids would most likely be:

choices.C: violet.
choices.D: blue.

questions.question: 33. Many stores sell blue or blue-purple grow lights for growing plants indoors. According to the results of Study 1, would this color of light be better than other colors to promote photosynthesis?

choices.A: Yes, since more bacteria were found in the blue region than in the other regions.
choices.B: Yes, since the grow lights emitted all colors except blue which inhibits photosynthesis.
choices.C: No, since bacteria that were found in regions other than the blue region indicated lack of oxygen.
choices.D: No, since more bacteria were found in the red and orange regions than in the blue region.

questions.question: 34. The activities of living systems are often affected by temperature. Which of the studies most likely required that the living material tested be exposed to the same temperature each time it was performed?

choices.C: Study 3 only
choices.D: Studies 1 and 2

questions.title: Passage VII
questions.article:
Solutions containing the purple permanganate ion (MnO4-) absorb visible light. The amount of light absorbed can be measured by a spectrometer. White visible light contains light of all colors, and each color is characterized by its wavelength. When light passes through a colored solution only certain colors or wavelengths are absorbed. The absorbance measured varies with each wavelength and also depends on the amount of MnO4- present in the solution. Absorbance readings are always adjusted for the absorbance of the blank (a solution prepared in the same way as the test solution except it does not contain MnO4-).

Experiment 1
Four standard solutions (solutions containing known concentrations of MnO4-) were prepared by dissolving a permanganate compound in acid. They were analyzed by a spectrometer at a wavelength of 530 nm (nanometers). The results are in Figure 1.


Experiment 2
Five kinds of steel pipe (A-E), all containing 0.2 to 2.0% of manganese metal (Mn), were obtained.Equal sections of each pipe were cut and their masses determined. The samples were dissolved in acid to react with the metal to form colorless manganese ion (Mn+2). An oxidant was added to chemically react with the Mn+2 and convert it to MnO4-. The solutions were then diluted with water to a total volume of 1 liter (L). The resulting test solutions were analyzed at the same wavelength used in Experiment 1. The results are in Table 1. A blank was prepared using a steel pipe containing no Mn and analyzed in the same manner. The blank had an absorbance of 0.015.
questions.question: 35. Which of the following is the sequence of steps that was used to produce the test solutions for Experiment 2?

choices.A: Steel pipe sample + water + acid + oxidant → test solution
choices.B: Steel pipe sample + acid + water + oxidant → test solution
choices.C: Steel pipe sample + water + oxidant + acid → test solution.
choices.D: Steel pipe sample + acid + oxidant + water → test solution

questions.title: Passage VII
questions.article:
Solutions containing the purple permanganate ion (MnO4-) absorb visible light. The amount of light absorbed can be measured by a spectrometer. White visible light contains light of all colors, and each color is characterized by its wavelength. When light passes through a colored solution only certain colors or wavelengths are absorbed. The absorbance measured varies with each wavelength and also depends on the amount of MnO4- present in the solution. Absorbance readings are always adjusted for the absorbance of the blank (a solution prepared in the same way as the test solution except it does not contain MnO4-).

Experiment 1
Four standard solutions (solutions containing known concentrations of MnO4-) were prepared by dissolving a permanganate compound in acid. They were analyzed by a spectrometer at a wavelength of 530 nm (nanometers). The results are in Figure 1.


Experiment 2
Five kinds of steel pipe (A-E), all containing 0.2 to 2.0% of manganese metal (Mn), were obtained.Equal sections of each pipe were cut and their masses determined. The samples were dissolved in acid to react with the metal to form colorless manganese ion (Mn+2). An oxidant was added to chemically react with the Mn+2 and convert it to MnO4-. The solutions were then diluted with water to a total volume of 1 liter (L). The resulting test solutions were analyzed at the same wavelength used in Experiment 1. The results are in Table 1. A blank was prepared using a steel pipe containing no Mn and analyzed in the same manner. The blank had an absorbance of 0.015.
questions.question: 36. Why did the chemist treat, the test solutions in Experiment 2 with oxidant before the test solutions were analyzed, although the standard solutions prepared in Experiment 1 were treated only with acid?

choices.A: The Mn in the test solutions would not dissolve in acid.
choices.B: The Mn in the test solutions could not be compared to the standard solutions unless it was converted to MnO4-.
choices.C: The Mn in the test solutions could not be compared to the standard solutions unless it was converted to Mn＋2.
choices.D: The Mn in the standard solutions would dissolve only in acid.

questions.article:

questions.question: 37. If not enough oxidant is added to convert all the Mn+2 to MnO4- in Experiment 2, how would the value of the absorbance be affected? The value of the absorbance would be:

choices.A: the same as if all the Mn+2 is converted, because the same mass of Mn is present.
choices.B: the same as if all the Mn+2 is converted, because the wavelength is the same.
choices.C: less than if all the Mn+2 is converted.
choices.D: greater than if all the Mn+2 is converted.

questions.question: 38. According to Experiment 2, which steel pipe has the highest content of Mn?

choices.C: Pipe C
choices.D: Pipe D

questions.question: 40. Copper (Cu) forms a blue solution of Cu+2 ions when dissolved in acid. Blue solutions absorb light at 675 nm. What changes in procedure would be necessary if a metal pipe containing Cu rather than Mn was analyzed using a spectrometer?

choices.A: The spectrometer would be set at 530 nm for the standard solutions containing Cu+2 ions and for the metal pipe test solution.
choices.B: The spectrometer would be set at 530 nm for the standard solutions containing Cu+2 ions and at 675 nm for the metal pipe test solution.
choices.C: The spectrometer would be set at 675 nm for the standard solutions containing Cu+2 ions and at 530 nm for the metal pipe test solution.
choices.D: The spectrometer would be set at 675 nm for the standard solutions containing Cu+2 ions and for the metal pipe test solution.
